intro: Rubus moluccanus var. fallax, commonly known as the Moluccan blackberry, is a variant of the blackberry plant native to parts of Southeast Asia. It is a shrub that typically grows to a height of 1–2 meters, featuring thorny stems and pinnate leaves with three to five leaflets. The plant produces small, dark red to black berries that are often used in traditional medicine and local cuisine. Its botanical characteristics include a complex inflorescence structure and a robust root system adapted to tropical and subtropical climates. It is valued for its ornamental appeal and edible fruits, though it can be invasive in certain environments.
